The '''2023 United Nations Climate Change Conference''' or '''Conference of the Parties of the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]]''', more commonly known as '''COP28''', was the 28th [[United Nations Climate Change conference]], held from 30 November to 13 December at [[Expo City Dubai|Expo City]], [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. The COP conference has been held annually (except 2020 due to the [[COVID-19]] pandemic)<ref>{{Cite web |title=Event: Glasgow Climate Change Conference (UNFCCC COP 26) {{!}} SDG Knowledge Hub {{!}} IISD |url=https://sdg.iisd.org/events/2020-un-climate-change-conference-unfccc-cop-26/ |access-date=2023-02-22 |language=en-US |archive-date=2021-10-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211017192030/https://sdg.iisd.org/events/2020-un-climate-change-conference-unfccc-cop-26/ |url-status=live }}</ref> since the [[Earth Summit|first UN climate agreement in 1992]]. The event is intended for governments to agree on policies to [[Climate change mitigation|limit global temperature rises]] and [[Climate adaptation|adapt to impacts]] associated with [[climate change]].<ref>{{cite news |author-last=Stallard |author-first=Esme |title=COP27: What is the Egypt climate conference and why is it important? |date=25 October 2022 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-63316362 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |access-date=27 October 2022 |archive-date=2023-02-14  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230214173620/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-63316362 |url-status=live }}</ref>

The conference was orginally scheduled to end on 12 December, but had to be extended following [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] objections on the final agreement.<ref>{{Cite news |last=El Dahan |first=Maha |date=13 December 2023 |title=COP28 agreeable to Saudis as it lets nations chart own course - source |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/cop28-agreeable-saudis-it-lets-nations-chart-own-course-source-2023-12-13/ |access-date=2023-12-20  |archive-date=2023-12-13  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231213141621/https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/cop28-agreeable-saudis-it-lets-nations-chart-own-course-source-2023-12-13/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On 13 December, the conference president, [[Sultan Al Jaber]] announced that a final compromise agreement between the countries involved had been reached. The deal commits all signatory countries to move away from carbon energy sources "in a just, orderly and equitable manner" to mitigate the worst effects of climate change, and reach [[Net zero emissions|net zero]] by 2050.<ref name=":032">{{Cite news |last1=Morton |first1=Adam |last2=Harvey |first2=Fiona |last3=Greenfield |first3=Patrick |date=13 December 2023 |title=Cop28 landmark deal agreed to 'transition away' from fossil fuels |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/13/cop28-landmark-deal-agreed-to-transition-away-from-fossil-fuels |url-status=live |access-date=13 December 2023 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The global pact was the first in the history of COP summits to explicitly mention the need to shift away from every type of fossil fuels, but it still received widespread The conference was widely criticised for its controversial president [[Sultan Al Jaber]], as well as its host country, the UAE, which is known for its opaque environmental record and role as a major producer of [[fossil fuel]]s.<ref name="Carrington 2023 t429" /> Al Jaber is the CEO of the [[Abu Dhabi National Oil Company]] (ADNOC), leading to concerns over conflict of interest.<ref name=":02" /> ==Background==
The United Arab Emirates is one of the most climate-vulnerable countries in the world, due to its very hot and humid climate. The observed annual average mean surface air temperature in the UAE has risen by 1.27 °C (2.29 °F) between 1990 and 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal |url=https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/ |access-date=2023-11-24 |website=climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org |language=en |archive-date=2021-09-08  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210908011654/https://climateknowledgeportal.worldbank.org/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Without a reduction in emissions, [[wet-bulb temperature]]s in the region are expected to cross 35 °C (95 °F) for a prolonged period of time by the 2070s.<ref>{{cite news |author-last1=Bell |author-first1=Jennifer |author-last2=Narayanan |author-first2=Ayush }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author-last=Schonhardt |author-first=Sara |title=Lose, lose, lose': Oil-producing Persian Gulf faces extreme heat and [[Persian Gulf]] are the regions with the highest number of heat-humidity extreme events in the world, and they have exceeded safe wet-bulb temperature thresholds several times.<ref>{{cite journal According to the [[Climate and Clean Air Coalition to Reduce Short-Lived Climate Pollutants|Climate & Clean Air Coalition]], the UAE is making efforts to reduce emissions in many ways across different sectors of its economy. Measures include promoting [[Organic farming|organic]] and [[hydroponic agriculture]], building the [[Etihad Rail]], reducing [[waste]] (especially [[food waste]]), and promoting a more [[circular economy]].<ref>{{cite web |title=United Arab Emirates |url=https://www.ccacoalition.org/partners/united-arab-emirates#:~:text=The%20UAE%20is%20situated%20in,of%20dust%20and%20sand%20storms. |website=Climate&Clean air coalition |publisher=United Nations |access-date=21 September 2023 |archive-date=2023-10-02  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231002113600/https://www.ccacoalition.org/partners/united-arab-emirates#:~:text=The%20UAE%20is%20situated%20in,of%20dust%20and%20sand%20storms. |url-status=live }}</ref>

The UAE pledged to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2050; the first Middle Eastern government to make such a pledge.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |date=30 October 2021 |title=A Major Persian Gulf Oil Producer Tries to Burnish Its Climate Credentials |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/30/business/uae-net-zero-cop26.html |url-status=live |access-date=2023-02-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211031140751/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/30/business/uae-net-zero-cop26.html |archive-date=2021-10-31 |author-last=Reed |author-first=Stanley}}</ref> It was the first country in the region to sign the [[Paris Agreement]] on 21 September 2016.<ref>{{Cite news |author-last=Wright |author-first=Caroline |date=17 February 2022 |title=How the UAE is Committing to Climate Change Action |work=Harvard Business Publishing |url=https://www.harvardbusiness.org/how-the-uae-is-committing-to-climate-change-action/ |access-date=2023-02-15  |archive-date=2023-03-21  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230321072623/https://www.harvardbusiness.org/how-the-uae-is-committing-to-climate-change-action/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |author-last=Alam |author-first=Tanzeed |date=28 September 2016 |title=The UAE has ratified the Paris Climate Agreement but what comes next? |url=https://wwf.panda.org/wwf_news/?279454/The%2DUAE%2Dhas%2Dratified%2Dthe%2DParis%2DClimate%2DAgreement%2Dbut%2Dwhat%2Dcomes%2Dnext |website=Panda.org |access-date=2023-02-15  |archive-date=2023-03-14  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230314071336/https://wwf.panda.org/wwf_news/?279454/The-UAE-has-ratified-the-Paris-Climate-Agreement-but-what-comes-next |url-status=live }}</ref> The country has invested $50 billion into clean energy internationally and promised an additional $50 billion by 2030.<ref>{{Cite web |author-last=Yellen |author-first=Davie |date=25 January 2023 |title=The road to COP28: Can 2023 reshape climate action and the global economy for the better? |url=https://www.catf.us/2023/01/the-road-to-cop28-can-2023-reshape-climate-action-and-the-global-economy-for-the-better/ |website=Clean Air Task Force |access-date=2023-02-15  |archive-date=2023-01-30  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230130053653/https://www.catf.us/2023/01/the-road-to-cop28-can-2023-reshape-climate-action-and-the-global-economy-for-the-better/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=17 June 2022 |title=President Sheikh Mohamed pledges $50 billion to tackle climate change at Biden meeting |work=thenationalnews.com |url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/government/2022/06/17/president-sheikh-mohamed-participates-in-climate-change-meeting-hosted-by-joe-biden/ |access-date=2023-02-15  |archive-date=2023-03-21  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230321072622/https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/government/2022/06/17/president-sheikh-mohamed-participates-in-climate-change-meeting-hosted-by-joe-biden/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In November 2022, the UAE agreed to partner with the [[United States]] to invest another $100 billion in clean energy.<ref>{{Cite news |author-last=Turak |author-first=Natasha |date=1 November 2022 |title=U.S. and UAE sign strategic partnership deal to spur $100 billion in clean energy investment |work=CNBC |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/11/01/us-and-uae-sign-strategic-partnership-deal-to-spur-100-billion-in-clean-energy-investment-.html |access-date=2023-02-15  |archive-date=2023-01-31  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230131205212/https://www.cnbc.com/2022/11/01/us-and-uae-sign-strategic-partnership-deal-to-spur-100-billion-in-clean-energy-investment-.html |url-status=live }}</ref>

The general public believed that the event would be an uneventful and boring one, without new outcomes.

== History ==
In early 2021, the [[United Arab Emirates]] offered to host the 2023 event,<ref name=":0" /> and in November 2021 the [[List of prime ministers of the United Arab Emirates|prime minister]] and [[Vice President of the United Arab Emirates|vice president]] of the United Arab Emirates, Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum|Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum]], announced that the UAE would be hosting the 2023 conference. It was the third time it was hosted by a member of [[OPEC]] after [[Qatar]] in 2012 and [[Indonesia]] in 2007.<ref>{{Cite news |date=12 November 2021 |title=Dubai ruler says UAE to host COP28 climate conference in 2023/ |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/cop/dubai-ruler-says-uae-host-cop28-climate-conference-2023-2021-11-11/ |url-status=live |access-date=2023-02-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230225115739/https://www.reuters.com/business/cop/dubai-ruler-says-uae-host-cop28-climate-conference-2023-2021-11-11/ |archive-date=2023-02-25}}</ref>

On 1 August 2023, the UAE allowed environmental activists to "assemble peacefully" at the summit and vowed to provide them a space to "make their voices heard", despite its laws that prohibit unauthorised protests.<ref>{{cite web |title=UAE vows to allow 'peaceful' assembly of climate activists at COP28 |website=France24 |date=2023-08-01 |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20230801-uae-vows-to-allow-peaceful-assembly-of-climate-activists-at-cop28-1 |access-date=2023-08-02 |archive-date=2023-08-01  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230801165354/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20230801-uae-vows-to-allow-peaceful-assembly-of-climate-activists-at-cop28-1 |url-status=live }}</ref>

==Global stocktake==
{{see also|Fossil fuel phase-out}}
In September 2023, in advance of the opening of COP28, the [[United Nations]] published the first two-year assessment of global progress in slowing down climate change, called the "[[global stocktake]]".<ref>Stanway, D. and Alkousaa, R., [https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/un-says-more-needed-on-all-fronts-meet-climate-goals-2023-09-08/ U.N. says more needed 'on all fronts' to meet climate goals] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231108075558/https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/un-says-more-needed-on-all-fronts-meet-climate-goals-2023-09-08/ |date=2023-11-08  }}, ''Reuters'', published 8 September 2023, accessed 8 November 2023</ref> This type of overview was established during [[2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP26]] in [[Glasgow]] and is scheduled to be repeated every five years.<ref>{{Cite news |author-last=Scott |author-first=Mike |date=9 February 2023 |title=ESG Watch: How the 'global stocktake' will force investors to pull up their socks on climate |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/sustainable-business/esg-watch-how-global-stocktake-will-force-investors-pull-up-their-socks-climate-2023-02-09/ |access-date=2023-02-15  |archive-date=2023-02-12  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230212150858/https://www.reuters.com/business/sustainable-business/esg-watch-how-global-stocktake-will-force-investors-pull-up-their-socks-climate-2023-02-09/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Background |url=https://unfccc.int/topics/global-stocktake#Background |website=United Nations Climate Change |access-date=8 November 2023 |archive-date=2021-11-03  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211103202323/https://unfccc.int/topics/global-stocktake#Background |url-status=live }}</ref> The report says that a [[Fossil fuel phase-out|phase-out of fossil fuels]] is needed. Previously the United Nations avoided making similar statements.<ref>{{cite news |author-last=Harvey |author-first=Fiona |title='A critical moment': UN warns world will miss climate targets unless fossil fuels phased out |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/sep/08/un-report-calls-for-phasing-out-of-fossil-fuels-as-paris-climate-goals-being-missed |access-date=21 September 2023 |agency=The Guardian |date=8 September 2023 |archive-date=2023-09-21  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230921103939/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/sep/08/un-report-calls-for-phasing-out-of-fossil-fuels-as-paris-climate-goals-being-missed |url-status=live }}</ref> Among the 17 key findings of the report are:<ref>{{cite report |title=Technical dialogue of the first global stocktake Synthesis report by the co-facilitators on the technical dialogue |date=8 September 2023 |publisher=United Nations |pages=6, 10, 13, 16, 32 |url=https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/sb2023_09_adv.pdf |access-date=21 September 2023 |archive-date=2023-09-09  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909102955/https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/sb2023_09_adv.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref>

* The [[Paris Agreement]] and the resulting climate action significantly helped in reducing emissions. In 2011 the projected warming by 2100 was 3.7–4.8 °C. After [[2022 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP27]] it was 2.4–2.6 °C and in the best case, if all pledges are accomplished, 1.7–2.1 °C.

* As of September 2023, the world is not on track to reach the targets of the Paris Agreement. For having a more than 50% chance of limiting temperature rise to 1.5 °C and more than 67% chance of limiting it to 2 °C, global emissions must peak by the year 2025.

* Trillions of dollars are needed for limiting warming to 1.5 °C. Financial flows need to significantly change.

* More effective international cooperation and collaboration are crucial for reaching the targets of the Paris Agreement.

On the starting day of the summit on 30 November 2023, a "loss and damage" fund to compensate poor states for the effects of climate change was agreed on. The fund aims to distribute funds to poor states harmed by climate change and is to be administered by the [[World Bank]]. Initial promises were made by the host (UAE) to donate $100 million to the fund, and by the United Kingdom ($75 million), United States ($24.5 million), Japan ($10 million) and Germany ($100 million).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/cop28-climate-summit-just-approved-a-loss-and-damage-fund-what-does-this-mean-218999|title=OP28 climate summit just approved a 'loss and damage' fund. In his opening speech of the conference, [[Charles III]] expressed alarm at rising levels of pollution, saying that the world was "dreadfully far off track" its climate targets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/01/king-charles-to-give-call-to-arms-cop28-opening-statement-says-pm|title=King Charles issues call to arms in Cop28 opening statement|first=Aletha|last=Adu|date=1 December 2023|access-date=3 December 2023|work=[[The Guardian]]|archive-date=2023-12-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231202113319/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/01/king-charles-to-give-call-to-arms-cop28-opening-statement-says-pm|url-status=live}}</ref> The British monarch warned that "we are carrying out a vast, frightening experiment of changing every ecological condition, all at once, at a pace that far outstrips nature's ability to cope".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/01/cop28-king-charles-warns-of-vast-frightening-experiment-on-natural-world|title=Cop28: King Charles warns of 'vast, frightening experiment' on natural world|first1=Fiona|last1=Harvey|first2=Nina|last2=Lakhani|first3=Aletha|last3=Adu|first4=Damian|last4=Carrington|first5=Patrick|last5=Greenfield|first6=Oliver|last6=Milman|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=1 December 2023|access-date=3 December 2023|archive-date=2023-12-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231203002533/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/01/cop28-king-charles-warns-of-vast-frightening-experiment-on-natural-world|url-status=live}}</ref>

On 1 December 2023 activists protested outside the venue, calling for [[ecocide]] — mass environmental destruction — to be made a crime at the [[International Criminal Court]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Torbey |first=Etienne |title=Climate Activists Protest At Entrance To COP28 Venue |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/climate-activists-protest-at-entrance-to-cop28-venue-680e4b83 |access-date=2023-12-04 |website=www.barrons.com |language=en-US |archive-date=2023-12-14  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214071146/https://www.barrons.com/news/climate-activists-protest-at-entrance-to-cop28-venue-680e4b83 |url-status=live }}</ref>

The head of the [[International Monetary Fund]], [[Kristalina Georgieva]], expressed satisfaction from the beginning of the conference because the [[Loss and damage (climate change)|loss and damage fund]] was created, but said that for further decarbonisation [[carbon pricing]] should be advanced and [[fossil fuel subsidies]] eliminated. Fossil fuel subsidies reached a record level of 7.1 trillion dollars in the year 2022, due to high fuel prices and inflation.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Al-Oraibi |first1=Mina |last2=Kamel |first2=Deena |title=Cop28 'successful from day one' with win on loss and damage fund, IMF chief says |url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/climate/cop28/2023/12/04/cop-28-successful-from-day-one-with-early-win-on-loss-and-damage-fund-imf-chief-says/ |website=COP 28 |date=4 December 2023 |access-date=4 December 2023 |archive-date=2023-12-04  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231204222450/https://www.thenationalnews.com/climate/cop28/2023/12/04/cop-28-successful-from-day-one-with-early-win-on-loss-and-damage-fund-imf-chief-says/ |url-status=live }}</ref> There are propositions for a creation of a global carbon market managed by the [[United Nations]] in the conference. Some steps are already done.<ref>{{cite web |title=Commission President advances global cooperation on carbon pricing in high-level event at COP28 |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/IP_23_6092 |website=European Commission |publisher=European Union |access-date=4 December 2023 |archive-date=2023-12-04  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231204222340/https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/IP_23_6092 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=COP 28 holds key to global carbon market that could help improve offsets |url=https://www.energyvoice.com/markets/542024/cop-28-holds-key-to-global-carbon-market-that-could-help-improve-offsets/ |website=Energy Voice |date=24 November 2023 |publisher=Bloomberg |access-date=4 December 2023 |archive-date=2023-12-04  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231204222353/https://www.energyvoice.com/markets/542024/cop-28-holds-key-to-global-carbon-market-that-could-help-improve-offsets/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Bedford |first1=Charles |title=At COP28 & beyond, fair carbon markets must be part of the climate finance solution (commentary) |url=https://news.mongabay.com/2023/11/at-cop28-beyond-fair-carbon-markets-must-be-part-of-the-climate-finance-solution-commentary/ |website=Mongabay |date=30 November 2023 |access-date=4 December 2023 |archive-date=2023-12-02  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231202090623/https://news.mongabay.com/2023/11/at-cop28-beyond-fair-carbon-markets-must-be-part-of-the-climate-finance-solution-commentary/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

On 2 December 2023, COP28 participants launched a declaration to triple [[Nuclear power|nuclear energy]] capacity from 2020 to 2050.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.energy.gov/articles/cop28-countries-launch-declaration-triple-nuclear-energy-capacity-2050-recognizing-key |date=2023-12-01 |title=At COP28, Countries Launch Declaration to Triple Nuclear Energy Capacity by 2050, Recognizing the Key Role of Nuclear Energy in Reaching Net Zero |work=energy.gov}}</ref> The declaration was unveiled by US climate envoy John Kerry, and signed by 25 countries: Armenia, Bulgaria, Canada, Croatia, Czech Republic, Finland, France, Ghana, Hungary, Jamaica, Japan, Moldova, Mongolia, Morocco, Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Korea, Sweden, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom and the United States. The signing countries pledged to implement policies to extend their nuclear capacities, stating that nuclear power played a key role in cutting carbon emissions to net zero.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/02/climate/cop28-nuclear-power.html |title=22 Countries Pledge to Triple Nuclear Capacity in Push to Cut Fossil Fuels |date=2023-12-02 |work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.world-nuclear-news.org/Articles/COP28-agreement-recognises-nuclear-s-role |title=COP28 agreement recognises nuclear's role |date=2023-12-13 |work=World nuclear news}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://energycentral.com/c/ec/world-pledges-triple-nuclear-power-cop28 |title=The World Pledges to Triple Nuclear Power at COP28 |date=2023-12-26 |work=Energy Central}}</ref>

On 3 December 2023, ''[[The Guardian]]'' revealed that COP28 President Sultan Al-Jaber had dismissed demands for a [[fossil fuel phaseout]], denying its basis in science and claiming it would prevent economic development.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/03/back-into-caves-cop28-president-dismisses-phase-out-of-fossil-fuels|title=Cop28 president says there is 'no science' behind demands for phase-out of fossil fuels|first1=Damian|last1=Carrington|first2=Ben|last2=Stockton|date=3 December 2023|access-date=5 December 2023|work=[[The Guardian]]|archive-date=2023-12-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231205165154/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/03/back-into-caves-cop28-president-dismisses-phase-out-of-fossil-fuels|url-status=live}}</ref> The following day, Al-Jaber held a press conference in which he stated he "respects science", thinks a phaseout of fossil fuel use is inevitable and claimed his comments were taken out of context.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/04/cop28-president-says-no-science-for-fossil-fuel-phase-out-claim-was-misinterpreted|title=Cop28 president forced into defence of fossil fuel phase-out claims|first=Damian|last=Carrington|date=4 December 2023|access-date=5 December 2023|work=[[The Guardian]]|archive-date=2023-12-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231205162521/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/04/cop28-president-says-no-science-for-fossil-fuel-phase-out-claim-was-misinterpreted|url-status=live}}</ref>

On 6 December 2023, [[Haitham al-Ghais]], the current OPEC Secretary-General, urged member nations to focus negotiations on reducing carbon emissions, rather than prohibiting the extraction and sale of fossil fuels.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Friedman |first=Lisa |date=8 December 2023 |title=OPEC Leader Tells Members to Block Any Climate Summit Deal to Curb Fossil Fuels |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/08/climate/opec-cop28-climate-oil.html |access-date=8 December 2023 |archive-date=2023-12-09  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231209020538/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/08/climate/opec-cop28-climate-oil.html |url-status=live }}</ref> As a reaction, [[Greenpeace]] published a press release calling for Arab countries to phase out fossil fuels by 2050, ensuring a [[just transition]]. Greenpeace said that "The latest research from Christian Aid and the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Vienna shows that both the UAE and Saudi Arabia face a GDP growth reduction of −72% by 2100 if the global temperature rise is allowed to reach 3°C."<ref>{{cite web |title=Arab countries must support UAE in bidding farewell to fossil fuels at COP28 |url=https://www.greenpeace.org/mena/en/arab-countries-cop28/ |website=Greenpeace |access-date=12 December 2023 |archive-date=2023-12-14  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214071146/https://www.greenpeace.org/mena/en/arab-countries-cop28/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The study called ''Mercury Rising: the economic impact of climate change on the Arabian Peninsula'' predicts a 69% drop in GDP growth for countries at the Persian Gulf in average, with the highest impact on [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Kuwait]], [[Qatar]], and the [[United Arab Emirates]] if temperatures will reach this level. If temperature rise will be limited to 1.5 degrees, the reduction in economic growth will be limited to 8.2% by 2050 and 36% by 2100.<ref>{{cite web |title=UAE RISKS UP TO −72% GDP GROWTH HIT DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE: REPORT |url=https://carboncopy.info/uae-risks-up-to-72-gdp-growth-hit-due-to-climate-change-report/ |website=Carbon copy |date=9 December 2023 |access-date=12 December 2023 |archive-date=2023-12-14  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231214072202/https://carboncopy.info/uae-risks-up-to-72-gdp-growth-hit-due-to-climate-change-report/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== Draft and final agreements ===
The COP28 draft agreement, published on 11 December, avoided calling for a fossil fuel phaseout. It was subsequently rejected by the [[Umbrella Group]] and the [[Alliance of Small Island States]], which described the draft as a "death certificate" for small island nations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/12/cop-28-australia-us-and-uk-say-they-wont-sign-agreement-that-would-be-death-certificate-for-small-islands|title=Cop28: Australia, US and UK say they won't sign agreement that would be 'death certificate' for small islands|first=Adam|last=Morton|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=12 December 2023|access-date=12 December 2023|archive-date=2023-12-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231212011105/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/dec/12/cop-28-australia-us-and-uk-say-they-wont-sign-agreement-that-would-be-death-certificate-for-small-islands|url-status=live}}</ref>

On the morning of 13 December, shortly after the start of the COP28's final plenary assembly, Al-Jaber announced that the participating countries had agreed to a compromise deal that encouraged all signatory states to end their dependence on fossil fuels "in a just, orderly and equitable manner", in order to prevent the worst outcome of climate change, while also working to achieve [[Net zero emissions|net zero]] by 2050.<ref name=":032"/><ref name=":122">{{Cite news |last=Plumer |first=Brad |date=13 December 2023 |title=In a First, Nations at Climate Summit Agree to Move Away From Fossil Fuels |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/13/climate/cop28-climate-agreement.html |url-status=live |access-date=13 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231213080049/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/13/climate/cop28-climate-agreement.html/ |archive-date=2023-12-13 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The agreement, which had been released to countries for consideration only four hours before being passed<ref name=":032"/> — although this aspect did not lead to any formal objections<ref name=":032"/> — also called for a tripling of global renewable energy capacity by 2030,<ref name=":032"/><ref name=":122"/> the development of numerous "zero- and low-emission technologies",<ref name=":032"/> further efforts "towards the phase-down of unabated coal power"<ref name=":032"/> and a cut in [[methane emissions]].<ref name=":122"/> China and India did not sign the pledge to triple their output of renewable energy, and committed to coal power instead.<ref name="Slav 2023 z572"/><ref name="Lin 2023 n100"/>

For the first time in the history of COP summits, the global pact explicitly mentioned the necessity to shift away from all kinds of fossil fuels;<ref name=":032"/><ref name=":122"/> however, the deal was widely criticised for not including a clear commitment to "phase out" or "phase down" fossil fuels — as requested by many participating countries, civil society groups and scientists — <ref name=":032"/> as well as a clear financial plan to help developing countries reach the goal of transitioning away from fossil fuels.<ref name=":032"/><ref>{{Cite web |last=Cotugno |first=Ferdinando |date=12 December 2023 |title=Cosa fare, come e quando: Cop28 è l'immagine di un mondo spaccato |url=https://www.editorialedomani.it/ambiente/cosa-fare-come-e-quando-cop28-e-limmagine-di-un-mondo-spaccato-pvv0i74f |access-date=13 December 2023 |website=Domani |language=it-IT |url-status=live }}</ref> Moreover, the choice to include [[carbon capture and storage]] in the list of "zero- and low-emission technologies" was questioned due to their relative expensiveness and The participants of the conference pledged 85 billion dollars to different climate issues and made 10 pledges:<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cop28.com/en/ |title=COP28 UAE - United Nations Climate Change Conference |website=COP 28 UAE |access-date=22 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231215125242/https://www.cop28.com/en/ |archive-date=2023-12-15 |url-status=live}}</ref>

Includes commitments to reduce negative health impacts from climate change in collaboration with [[Indigenous peoples]], women, local communities and health workers, prevent [[Zoonosis|zoonotic spillover]].<ref>{{cite web |title=COP28 UAE DECLARATION ON CLIMATE AND HEALTH |url=https://www.cop28.com/en/cop28-uae-declaration-on-climate-and-health |website=COP 28 UAE |access-date=22 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231212211503/https://www.cop28.com/en/cop28-uae-declaration-on-climate-and-health |archive-date=2023-12-12 |url-status=live}}</ref>

The declaration includes commitments to promote peace, environmental policies that support peace, prevent climate change from increasing conflict, help and empower people affected by environmental degradation and conflict.<ref>{{cite web |title=COP28 DECLARATION ON CLIMATE, RELIEF, RECOVERY AND PEACE |url=https://www.cop28.com/en/cop28-declaration-on-climate-relief-recovery-and-peace |website=COP 28 UAE |access-date=22 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231212190228/https://www.cop28.com/en/cop28-declaration-on-climate-relief-recovery-and-peace |archive-date=2023-12-12 |url-status=live}}</ref>

The countries pledge to refer to energy efficiency as "first fuel" and double the rate of energy efficiency increase "from around 2% to over 4% every year until 2030". They also pledged to triple the capacity of renewable energy by 2030, ensuring a [[just transition]], increase renewable energy use and energy efficiency in an "environmentally responsible manner".<ref>{{cite web |title=GLOBAL RENEWABLES AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY PLEDGE |url=https://www.cop28.com/en/global-renewables-and-energy-efficiency-pledge |website=COP 28 UAE |access-date=22 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231212203448/https://www.cop28.com/en/global-renewables-and-energy-efficiency-pledge |archive-date=2023-12-12 |url-status=live}}</ref>

The signers pledged among others to cut GHG emissions from the cooling industry by 68% by 2050, increase the efficiency rate of air conditioning equipment by half by the year 2030, make a national plan for cooling, increase green spaces and blue spaces in cities and promote [[passive cooling]] (that can "reduce a building’s cooling load by more than 25%").<ref>{{cite web |title=GLOBAL COOLING PLEDGE FOR COP28 |url=https://www.cop28.com/en/global-cooling-pledge-for-cop28 |website=COP 28 UAE |access-date=22 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231212190238/https://www.cop28.com/en/global-cooling-pledge-for-cop28 |archive-date=2023-12-12 |url-status=live}}</ref>

The statement recognizes that the problems of [[climate change]], [[biodiversity loss]], [[land degradation]] ocean degradation and social inequality are interconnected and cannot be solved separately. Therefore, the signers pledge to unify the plans to solve the problems into one integrated strategy.<ref>{{cite web |title=COP28 JOINT STATEMENT ON CLIMATE, NATURE AND PEOPLE |url=https://www.cop28.com/en/joint-statement-on-climate-nature |website=COP 28 UAE |access-date=22 December 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231212041825/https://www.cop28.com/en/joint-statement-on-climate-nature |archive-date=2023-12-12 |url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Treatment of migrant workers ===
The UAE has been adapting its conference facility, the prior site for [[Expo 2020]], to host the COP28 climate conference. FairSquare, a UK-based human rights group, released a report based on testimonies and photographs, stating that the migrant workers were being exposed to dangerously hot weather and humidity to prepare for the climate summit. According to the rights group, in September 2023, a dozen migrant workers from Asia and Africa were working outdoors in temperatures hitting 42 °C (107.6 °F) despite a midday ban. COP28 denied the allegations and claimed that no evidence of the midday ban's breach was found. A worksite supervisor said most of the work is done at night, but some has to be done whenever possible. A COP28 spokesperson said contractors were required to have worker heat safety plans and weather stations that monitor the [[Thermal work limit|Thermal Work Limit]], as well as taking into account heat and humidity metrics including wet and dry bulb temperature and wind speed.<ref>{{cite news |author-last=Lakhani |author-first=Nina |title=Migrant workers toil in perilous heat to prepare for Cop28 climate talks in UAE |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/20/cop28-migrant-workers-uae-heat-climate-crisis |access-date=31 October 2023 |work=The Guardian |date=20 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231020071429/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/20/cop28-migrant-workers-uae-heat-climate-crisis |archive-date=20 October 2023}}</ref>

=== Digital surveillance ===
Ahead of COP28, [[Amnesty International]] raised concerns that the UAE might continue to use digital surveillance to spy on human rights defenders and civil society members in the UAE, including the COP28 participants. According to Amnesty International's Disrupting Surveillance Team, the UAE had a record of using digital surveillance to "crush dissents and stifle freedom of expression". Amnesty's view of the UAE's promise to offer a "platform for activists' voices" would be unachievable without respect for the human rights of privacy and the right of peaceful assembly. Amnesty opposed the "unlawful electronic surveillance of conference participants [and of] Emirati nationals and residents". [[Sultan Al Jaber]], the president of COP28, has drawn criticism for asserting there is no scientific basis for phasing out fossil fuels to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, a claim revealed by ''The Guardian'' and the Centre for Climate Reporting. Described as "incredibly concerning" and bordering on climate denial, his comments contradict the stance of UN Secretary-General António Guterres. The remarks were made during a confrontational exchange with Mary Robinson, chair of the Elders group, at a live online event on November 21. ''The Times'' noted widespread condemnation of Al Jaber's statements at COP28, where numerous countries, including the UK and EU members, advocated for the phased reduction of unabated fossil fuels. In contrast, former US vice president Al Gore emphasized the historical significance of a potential COP28 agreement to phase out fossil fuels, considering it one of the most crucial events in human history. Simultaneously, BBC News reported a substantial increase in the United Arab Emirates' oil production, with Adnoc, the state oil firm, projected to drill 42% more by 2030. Despite this, Adnoc claims it aims to enhance climate-friendliness, including venturing into renewable energy, amid the global call for fossil fuel reduction.<ref>{{Cite web |title=COP28 president says there is 'no science' behind demands for phase-out of fossil fuels |url=https://www.carbonbrief.org/daily-brief/cop28-president-says-there-is-no-science-behind-demands-for-phase-out-of-fossil-fuels/ |access-date=2023-12-13 |website=Carbon Brief |language=en |archive-date=2023-12-04  |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231204131434/https://www.carbonbrief.org/daily-brief/cop28-president-says-there-is-no-science-behind-demands-for-phase-out-of-fossil-fuels/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
